title: EU to Commission Mobile Responsive Launch System Studies
summary:
The European Commission has launched a call for studies to examine the potential of a mobile responsive launch system, a capability that would enable the rapid deployment of satellites into orbit from non-permanent (mobile) ground platforms. In the preamble to the call published on 10 July, the Commission notes that due to an increasing number […]
The post EU to Commission Mobile Responsive Launch System Studies appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: The European Commission has launched a call for studies to examine the potential of a mobile responsive launch system. The capability would enable the rapid deployment of satellites into orbit from non-permanent (mobile) ground platforms. The total budget for the call is €1.95 million, with up to €650,000 available for each study.

title: New MetOp Second Generation weather satellite returns first data
summary: Less than three weeks since the first MetOp Second Generation weather satellite, MetOp-SG-A1, was launched, this remarkable new satellite has already started transmitting data from two of its cutting-edge instruments, offering a tantalising glimpse of what’s to come.
detailed_news: The MetOp Second Generation (MetOp-SG) mission builds on the proven success of the first-generation MetOp satellites. It will provide the essential data needed to strengthen weather prediction models and deepen our understanding of Earth’s changing climate. Launched on 13 August, aboard an Ariane 6 rocket from the European Spaceport in French Guiana, Eumetsat is currently putting the new satellite through a rigorous commissioning phase. Metop-SG-A1 is expected to require months of thorough testing and calibration before any data are released to Member State meteorological services and other users. Both the MWS and RO will provide inputs of unprecedented precision for numerical weather predication. The curves are plotted alongside ECMWF forecast data. The RO measurements refine and update temperature and humidity structure predictions.

title: Launch Roundup: SpaceX to launch five Falcon 9 missions this week
summary:
Five Falcon 9 launches make up the launch manifest for this week. Collectively, four of…
The post Launch Roundup: SpaceX to launch five Falcon 9 missions this week appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: The first of SpaceX’s five scheduled Falcon 9 missions for this week, Starlink Group 17-8, is due to launch from Space Launch Complex 4 East (SLC-4E) at Vandenberg Space Force Base (VSFB) in California on Tuesday, Sept. 2. A new booster, B1097, is expected to support this mission. The payload will consist of 24 Starlink v2 Mini satellites launched due south to a Sun-synchronous orbit (SSO) The first stage booster is powered by nine Merlin 1D engines, while the second stage utilizes a single vacuum-optimized Merlin engine. Starlink Group 10-57 mission is expected to launch on Thursday, Sept. 4, at 7:18 AM EDT (11:18 UTC) from Launch Complex 39A (LC-39A) at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Falcon 9’s payload will consist of 28 Starlink v2 Mini satellites launched northeast to a low Earth orbit (LEO) Falcon 9 | Nusantara 5 (Lima) mission will place an Indonesian high-throughput telecommunications satellite into geostationary transfer orbit.

title: Double trouble: Solar Orbiter traces superfast electrons back to Sun
summary: The European Space Agency-led Solar Orbiter mission has split the flood of energetic particles flung out into space from the Sun into two groups, tracing each back to a different kind of outburst from our star.
detailed_news: European Space Agency-led Solar Orbiter mission has split the flood of energetic particles flung out into space from the Sun into two groups. Researchers trace each back to a different kind of outburst from our star. The study is the most comprehensive of SEE events to date, and produces a catalogue that will only grow through Solar orbiter’s lifetime. The study fulfils an important goal of Solar Orbiter: to trace ejected particles back to their sources at the Sun. Crucially, the finding is important for our understanding of space weather, where accurate forecasting is essential to keep our spacecraft operational and safe. One of the two kinds of SEE events is more important for space weather: that connected to CMEs, which tend to hold more high-energy particles.

title: Trump’s Labor Union EO Designates NASA as Primarily An Intelligence/National Security Agency
summary: An Executive Order issued by President Trump to exclude NASA and other agencies from collective bargaining rights does so by designating them as having intelligence or national security as a […]
detailed_news: President Trump issued an Executive Order (EO) on Thursday excluding a number of agencies and agency subdivisions from collective bargaining representation. Some agencies were excluded from FSLMRS when the law was written, including the FBI, CIA, and the National Security Agency. Presidents may add to the list by Executive Order if an agency is “determined to have as a primary function intelligence, counterintelligence, investigative, or national security work” NASA was created as a civilian agency to emphasize the U.S. goal of using space for peaceful purposes and to encourage international cooperation. A White House fact sheet cited NASA’s development and operation of “advanced air and space technologies” as a justification for designating the agency as having intelligence, counterintelligence, investigative, or national security work as a “primary function”

title: Scientists investigate moonquakes using Apollo 17 samples, LRO observations
summary:
While Earth and Mars are known for their intense surface quakes, other terrestrial bodies in…
The post Scientists investigate moonquakes using Apollo 17 samples, LRO observations appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Moonquakes are rare and significantly weaker than earthquakes. The most powerful moonquakes reach magnitudes of around 5.0. Moonquakes occur along active fault lines on the lunar surface. These fault lines are cracks in the Moon’s crust that form due to the Moon's shrinking as its interior slowly cools. Scientists have identified thousands of active faults along the lunar surface that may be regularly producing moonquakes. For their study, the scientists analyzed surface changes near the Lee-Lincoln fault in the Taurus-Littrow valley. A magnitude 3.0 moonquake rattles the region once every 5.6 million years. NASA/JSC/ASU: August 20, 2025, August 17, 2025 and August 31, 2025. title: What’s Happening in Space Policy August 31-September 6, 2025
summary: Here is SpacePolicyOnline.com’s list of space policy events for the week of August 31-September 6, 2025 and any insight we can offer about them. The House and Senate are in […]
detailed_news: The Senate Commerce Committee will hold a hearing on Wednesday entitled “There’s a Bad Moon on the Rise: How Congress and NASA Can Thwart China in the Space Race” The hearing isn’t only about the Artemis program, but it certainly will be a key focus. The House plans to take up their NDAA bill next week. The Commerce-Justice-Science (CJS) bill that funds NASA was approved by the Senate Appropriations Committee on July 17. The House Appropriations Committee was supposed to mark up the CJS bill the day before recess was scheduled to begin, but the House adjourned a day early so the markup was postponed. Several other great events are on tap this week as well, including a discussion of “Space Law Across Borders” SpacePolicyOnline.com has the right (but not the obligation) to monitor the comments and to remove any materials it deems inappropriate. We do not post comments that include links to other websites since we have no control over that content nor can we verify the security of such links. Those and other events we know about as of Sunday morning are shown below.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX’s Sunday morning Falcon 9 launch will send 1,900th Starlink to orbit in 2025
summary: SpaceX continues its blistering pace of orbital launches with its ninth and final Starlink launch of August. It’s targeting liftoff of its Falcon 9 rocket from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station at 7:17 a.m. EDT (1117 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX will launch the Starlink 10-14 mission using the Falcon 9 first stage booster 1077, which will make its 23rd trip to space and back. Sunday’s launch will the 108th of the year. SpaceX plans to launch at least 170 Falcon 9 rockets across 2025, with the majority of those supporting its Starlink constellation. A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket successfully took off early Sunday with a Japanese video and data relay satellite. The rocket then stuck a landing on a barge stationed nearly 400 miles east of Cape Canaveral. The launch was part of a joint venture between SpaceX and a Japanese satellite company.

title: Rocket Lab inaugurates LC-3 at Wallops
summary:
Rocket Lab has inaugurated Launch Complex 3 (LC-3) for its Neutron rocket, which is set…
The post Rocket Lab inaugurates LC-3 at Wallops appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Rocket Lab has inaugurated Launch Complex 3 (LC-3) for its Neutron rocket. The rocket is set to launch from the Mid-Atlantic Regional Spaceport (MARS) on Wallops Island, Virginia. The pad was completed in under two years by a Virginia-based team of engineers. Rocket Lab aims for Neutron’s maiden flight by the end of 2025. The first stage is powered by nine Archimedes engines (up from an original seven), while the second stage uses one vacuum-optimized archimedes engine. Both stages use liquid oxygen (LOX) and liquid methane as propellants, enabling reusability.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 24 Starlink satellites into polar orbit
summary: The Starlink 17-7 mission is the penultimate planned launch of these broadband satellites in August. SpaceX is targeting liftoff from pad 4E at 8:08 p.m. PDT (11:08 p.m. EDT / 0308 UTC).
detailed_news: The mission dubbed Starlink 17-7 will be the fourth and final Starlink mission to launch from California in August. SpaceX continues to bolster its low Earth orbit Starlink constellation as it rolls out the service to more countries and territories around the world. According to numbers tracked by astronomer and expert orbital tracker, Jonathan McDowell, there are more than 8,200 Starlink satellites on orbit.

title: SpaceX got good heat shield data for Starship, so what comes next?
summary: "The latest upgrades are looking good!"
detailed_news: SpaceX's Starship rocket made a soft landing in the Indian Ocean on Tuesday. A striking orange discoloration of the second stage led to all sorts of speculation. SpaceX founder Elon Musk provided some clarity on this discolration on Thursday. Musk: "The latest upgrades are looking good!" SpaceX is working on a range of missions that could lead to operational Starlink satellites. The company is also likely to conduct an in-orbit refueling test. This is a key step toward allowing Starships to go to the Moon (for NASA's Artemis Program) and Mars.

title: NASA Astronaut Megan McArthur Retires
summary: NASA astronaut Megan McArthur has retired, concluding a career spanning more than two decades. A veteran of two spaceflights, McArthur logged 213 days in space, including being the first woman to pilot a SpaceX Dragon spacecraft and the last person to “touch” the Hubble Space Telescope with the space shuttle’s robotic arm. McArthur launched as […]
detailed_news: Megan McArthur was the first woman to pilot a SpaceX Dragon spacecraft. She was the last person to “touch” the Hubble Space Telescope with the space shuttle’s robotic arm. McArthur has served in various technical and leadership roles within NASA. She also served as the assistant director of flight operations for the International Space Station Program. “I am grateful I had the opportunity to contribute to this work, and I’m excited to watch our brilliant engineers and scientists at NASA conquer new challenges,” says Shaneequa Vereen. To learn more about NASA’s astronauts and their contributions to space exploration, visit: https://www.nasa.gov/astronauts.

title: Landsat 9 Sees Buccaneer Archipelago
summary: The Operational Land Imager on Landsat 9 captured this image of Buccaneer Archipelago on June 11, 2025. The scene encapsulates the striking interactions between land and water in the area where King Sound opens to the Indian Ocean. The powerful tidal currents stir up sediment in shallow areas, producing the beautiful turquoise swirls visible in this image. This […]
detailed_news: The Operational Land Imager on Landsat 9 captured this image of Buccaneer Archipelago on June 11, 2025. The scene encapsulates the striking interactions between land and water in the area where King Sound opens to the Indian Ocean. The powerful tidal currents stir up sediment in shallow areas, producing the beautiful turquoise swirls visible in this image.

title: Webb observations of interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: James Webb Space Telescope observed interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS on 6 August 2025 using its Near-Infrared Spectrograph. Webb is one of several space telescopes studying this comet, helping to reveal its size, physical properties, and chemical composition. While the comet poses no threat to Earth, such observations support astronomers in their ongoing mission to find, track, and better understand objects in our Solar System.

title: Hubble Homes in on Galaxy’s Star Formation
summary: This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image features a galaxy whose asymmetric appearance may be the result of a galactic tug of war. Located 35 million light-years away in the constellation Leo, the spiral galaxy Messier 96 is the brightest of the galaxies in its group. The gravitational pull of its galactic neighbors may be responsible […]
detailed_news: The gravitational pull of its galactic neighbors may be responsible for Messier 96’s uneven distribution of gas and dust, asymmetric spiral arms, and off-center galactic core. This asymmetric appearance is on full display in the new Hubble image that incorporates data from observations in ultraviolet, near infrared, and visible/optical light.

title: Week in images: 25-29 August 2025
summary: Week in images: 25-29 August 2025
detailed_news: CNN.com will feature iReporter photos in a weekly Travel Snapshots gallery. Please submit your best shots for next week. Visit CNN.com/Travel next Wednesday for a new gallery of snapshots. Click here for the next gallery of iReporters' snapshots.

title: Avio Signs New Tactical Propulsion Agreement with US Armed Forces
summary:
Italian rocket builder Avio has signed a new contract with the US Armed Forces for the production of solid rocket motors used to power tactical missiles. In 2022, Avio set up a US-based subsidiary in Delaware. In its 2023 year-end financial report, the company explained that it had launched the subsidiary after identifying a major […]
The post Avio Signs New Tactical Propulsion Agreement with US Armed Forces appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Italian rocket builder Avio has signed a new contract with the US Armed Forces for the production of solid rocket motors used to power tactical missiles. In 2022, Avio set up a US-based subsidiary in Delaware. The company explained that it had launched the subsidiary after identifying a major shortfall in tactical propulsion production capacity in the US.

title: NASA, NOAA prep spacecraft trio to study the Sun and its impacts
summary: NASA’s Interstellar Mapping and Acceleration Probe (IMAP) will be the primary payload on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket launching no earlier than Sep. 23. The vehicle is joined by the Carruthers Geocorona Observatory and NOAA’s Space Weather Follow-On - Lagrange 1 (SWFO-L1) observatory.
detailed_news: NASA’s Interstellar Mapping and Acceleration Probe (IMAP) will study the Sun and its effects on Earth and across the solar system. IMAP is joined by the Carruthers Geocorona Observatory and the Space Weather Follow-On – Lagrange 1 (SWFO-L1) observatory. All three spacecraft are fueled for launch, which is scheduled for no earlier than Sep. 23. SWFO-L1 will be capable of sending back solar weather data in less than five minutes. Carruthers will also study space weather, specifically, it’s interplay with this exosphere. Engineers hope to fly the rotorcraft four more times in the next two weeks before calling it quits.

title: Dusty wisps round a dusty disc
summary: For this new Picture of the Month feature, the NASA/ESA/CSA James Webb Space Telescope has provided a fantastic new view of IRAS 04302+2247, a planet-forming disc located about 525 light-years away in a dark cloud within the Taurus star-forming region. With Webb, researchers can study the properties and growth of dust grains within protoplanetary discs like this one, shedding light on the earliest stages of planet formation.
detailed_news: James Webb Space Telescope has provided a fantastic new view of IRAS 04302+2247, a planet-forming disc located about 525 light-years away in the Taurus star-forming region. With Webb, researchers can study the properties and growth of dust grains within protoplanetary discs like this one. ESA was responsible for the development and qualification of Ariane 5 adaptations for the Webb mission. ESA also provided the workhorse spectrograph NIRSpec and 50% of the mid-infrared instrument MIRI. Webb is an international partnership between NASA, ESA and the Canadian Space Agency (CSA)

title: NASA Awards Spaceflight Operations, Systems Organization Contract
summary: NASA has awarded ASCEND Aerospace & Technology of Cape Canaveral, Florida, the Contract for Organizing Spaceflight Mission Operations and Systems (COSMOS), to provide services at the agency’s Johnson Space Center in Houston. The COSMOS is a single award, indefinite-delivery/indefinite-quantity contract valued at $1.8 billion that begins its five-year base period no earlier than Dec. 1, […]
detailed_news: The COSMOS is a single award, indefinite-delivery/indefinite-quantity contract valued at $1.8 billion. Work performed under the contract will support NASA’s Flight Operation Directorate. Services include Mission Control Center systems, training systems, mockup environments.

title: NASA Invites Media to Learn About New Missions to Map Sun’s Influence
summary: NASA will hold a media teleconference at 12 p.m. EDT on Thursday, Sept. 4, to discuss the agency’s upcoming Sun and space weather missions, IMAP (Interstellar Mapping and Acceleration Probe) and Carruthers Geocorona Observatory. The two missions are targeting launch on the same rocket no earlier than Tuesday, Sept. 23. The IMAP mission will map […]
detailed_news: The IMAP mission will map the boundaries of our heliosphere. The Carruthers Geocorona Observatory will image the ultraviolet glow of Earth’s exosphere. This data will help scientists understand how space weather from the Sun shapes the exosphere and ultimately impacts our planet.

title: NASA Marsquake Data Reveals Lumpy Nature of Red Planet’s Interior
summary: Rocky material that impacted Mars lies scattered in giant lumps throughout the planet’s mantle, offering clues about Mars’ interior and its ancient past. What appear to be fragments from the aftermath of massive impacts on Mars that occurred 4.5 billion years ago have been detected deep below the planet’s surface. The discovery was made thanks […]
detailed_news: Rocky material that impacted Mars lies scattered in giant lumps throughout the planet’s mantle. The ancient impacts released enough energy to melt continent-size swaths of the early crust and mantle. They offer a record preserved only on worlds like Mars, whose lack of tectonic plates has kept its interior from being churned up. Lumps of material appear to be material with a different composition than the surrounding mantle. Lumps likely arrived as giant asteroids or other rocky material that struck Mars during the early solar system. The fact that such fine structures are still visible today tells us Mars hasn’t undergone the vigorous churning that would have smoothed out these lumps.

title: NASA, International Astronauts to Address Students from New York
summary: NASA astronaut Jonny Kim and JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency) astronaut Kimiya Yui will connect with students in New York as they answer prerecorded science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) questions aboard the International Space Station. The Earth-to-space call will begin at 9:20 a.m. EDT on Friday, Sept. 5, and will stream live on the […]
detailed_news: The Earth-to-space call will begin at 9:20 a.m. EDT on Friday, Sept. 5. The Computer School will host this event in New York for middle school students. The goal of this event is to expose students to the real-world experiences and engineering challenges of astronauts working and living aboard the International Space Station.

title: NASA Scientists Help Maryland County Plan to Beat Summer Heat Risks
summary: Thousands of Americans are impacted each summer by excessive heat and humidity, some suffering from heat-related illnesses when the body can’t cool itself down. Data from NASA satellites could help local governments reduce the sweltering risks, thanks to a collaboration between NASA scientists and officials in Prince George’s County, Maryland. The effort demonstrates how local […]
detailed_news: NASA scientists and officials in Prince George’s County, Maryland, collaborated on the study. Data from NASA satellites could help local governments reduce the sweltering risks. The data also show how temperatures have responded to changing land use and construction. A NASA guide is available to aid other communities who hope to duplicate the Prince George's County study. Prince George’s County uses NASA resources and expertise in its efforts to improve safety and health. One of the greatest benefits of the collaboration is the boost in credibility that comes from incorporating NASA resources. “Working with NASA builds confidence that the decision-making process is based firmly in science,” Abe said.

title: NASA’s Chandra Reveals Star’s Inner Conflict Before Explosion
summary: The inside of a star turned on itself before it spectacularly exploded, according to a new study from NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory. Today, this shattered star, known as the Cassiopeia A supernova remnant, is one of the best-known, well-studied objects in the sky. Over three hundred years ago, however, it was a giant star on […]
detailed_news: Cassiopeia A was a giant star on the brink of self-destruction. New study reveals that just hours before it exploded, the star’s interior violently rearranged itself. Last-minute shuffling of its stellar belly has profound implications for understanding how massive stars explode and how their remains behave afterwards. Cassiopeia A, or Cas A, was a star on the brink of self-destruction. In composition it resembled an onion with layers rich in different elements such as hydrogen, helium, carbon, silicon, sulfur, calcium, and neon. When that iron core grew beyond a certain mass, the star could no longer support its own weight. The outer layers fell into the collapsing core, then rebounded as a supernova.

title: With recent Falcon 9 milestones, SpaceX vindicates its “dumb” approach to reuse
summary: The company's workhorse continues its stellar performance.
detailed_news: SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket continued to hit some impressive milestones this week. The company's workhorse continues its stellar performance. Both occurred during relatively anonymous launches of the company's Starlink satellites. The milestones underscore the value of first-stage reuse, which SpaceX pioneered over the last decade. United Launch Alliance says its approach is superior to SpaceX's. The company dubbed its approach SMART, an acronym for Sensible Modular Autonomous Return Technology. According to the United Launch Alliance analysis in 2015, the SMART plan would result in cost savings as soon as the second launch of a booster.

title: MaiaSpace Completes Burst Test Campaign and Begins Orbital Vehicle Development
summary:
French rocket builder and ArianeGroup subsidiary MaiaSpace has announced the completion of a months-long test campaign that subjected several subscale prototypes of its propellant tanks to high-pressure burst tests. In a 27 August update, the company revealed that over the six-month campaign it had conducted 15 burst tests of subscale propellant tanks, which MaiaSpace calls […]
The post MaiaSpace Completes Burst Test Campaign and Begins Orbital Vehicle Development appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: French rocket builder MaiaSpace has announced the completion of a months-long test campaign. The company subjected several subscale prototypes of its propellant tanks to high-pressure burst tests. The data collected will be used to validate mechanical models that will inform the final design of the full-scale propellant Tanks.

title: Katie Bisci: Resourcing for Big Science
summary: Deputy Project Manager for Resources – Goddard Space Flight Center How are you helping set the stage for the Roman mission? I’m a deputy project manager for resources on the Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope team, sharing the role with Kris Steeley. Together, we oversee the business team, finance, outreach, scheduling, and more. I focus […]
detailed_news: Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope deputy project manager. Her job is to help along the technical parts of the mission, while supporting cost and schedule control. The Roman team is amazing, and those relationships are what keep me excited to come to work every day. She says the best part about Roman is the people. I’ve learned about how the Hubble Space Telescope , Webb, and Roman all build on each other during my time on this project. It’s really fulfilling to be a small part of something so big. I’m usually at their sports games or chauffeuring them around to one event or another.

title: Izaña-2 joins the laser game to track space debris
summary: In Tenerife, Spain, stands a unique duo: ESA’s Izaña-1 and Izaña-2 laser-ranging stations. Together, they form an optical technology testbed of the European Space Agency that takes the monitoring of space debris and satellites to a new level while maturing new technologies for commercialisation.
detailed_news: Space debris is a threat to satellites and is rapidly becoming a daily concern for satellite operators. The Space Safety Programme helps develop new technologies to detect and track debris. One of these efforts takes place at the Izaña station in Tenerife. There, ESA and partner companies are testing how to deliver precise orbit data on demand with laser-based technologies.

title: Over Soroya Ridge & Onward!
summary: Written by Eleanor Moreland, Ph.D. Student Collaborator at Rice University Perseverance has continued exploring beyond the rim of Jezero crater, spending time last week at Parnasset conducting a mini-campaign on aeolian bedforms. After wrapping up that work, three separate drives brought Perseverance further southeast to an outcrop named Soroya. Soroya was first picked out from […]
detailed_news: Perseverance spent last week at Parnasset conducting a mini-campaign on aeolian bedforms. Three separate drives brought Perseverance further southeast to an outcrop named Soroya. Soroya was first picked out from orbital images as a target of interest because, as can be seen in the above image, it appears as a much lighter color compared to the surroundings.

title: Live coverage: Record-breaking 30th flight planned for SpaceX Falcon 9 booster as it launches Starlink satellites
summary: The Starlink 10-11 mission features the first launch of a booster on its 30th flight. SpaceX is targeting liftoff of its Falcon 9 rocket from Launch Complex 39A at 1:27 a.m. EDT (0527 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX second Starlink launch in 24 hours will see the flight of a Falcon 9 booster for a record-setting 30th time. Liftoff from pad 39A at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center is scheduled for 1:27 a.m. EDT (0527 UTC) Thursday. Starlink 10-11 mission will place another 28 Starlink V2 Mini broadband internet satellites into the low Earth orbit constellation.

title: Russia’s state-run human spaceflight company may be near bankruptcy
summary: "A significant part of the team has lost motivation and a sense of shared responsibility."
detailed_news: Igor Maltsev, chief of RSC Energia, says his corporation is in a "critical" state. He says the company is struggling to pay wages and deliver products it is contracted to build. "A significant part of the team has lost motivation and a sense of shared responsibility," he says. Ars Technica has been separating the signal from the noise for over 25 years. With our unique combination of technical savvy and wide-ranging interest in the technological arts and sciences, Ars is the trusted source in a sea of information. After all, you don’t need to know everything, only what’s important.

title: Patagonia Glacier retreat, Chile
summary: Patagonia, Chile. Left: September 18, 1986. Right: August 5, 2002. The 1986 image shows the region prior to a major retreat of the glaciers. The 2002 image shows a retreat of nearly 10 kilometers (6.2 miles) of the glacier on the left side. The smaller glacier on the right has receded more than 2 kilometers (1.2 miles). In front of the smaller glacier, two ribbon lakes have formed behind the debris left by the glacier’s advance. Scientists and government managers are using satellite imagery like this to monitor the retreat of the glaciers and the impact on water bodies caused by the changes in the glaciers’ size and direction.
detailed_news: NASA explores the unknown in air and space, innovates for the benefit of humanity, and inspires the world through discovery. NASA Earth Science helps Americans respond to challenges and societal needs — such as wildland fires, hurricanes, and water supplies. Explore Earth Science data at: http://www.nasa.gov/earth.

title: The Starship Program rises from the ashes of Block 2 with Ship 37
summary:
Going into Flight 10, SpaceX was having a down year with the Starship program. Following…
The post The Starship Program rises from the ashes of Block 2 with Ship 37 appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX has completed Flight 10 of the Starship program. The first attempt was scrubbed due to problems with the supply line for LOX. Crews used a motorized winch at the top of the tower to reinstall a new supply hose. Flight 10 ended with both vehicles performing controlled splashdowns in the water. SpaceX's Starship Flight 10 took off from Pad 1 (A) at 6:30:00 p.m. Central Daylight Time. This was the second-to-last flight of a Block 2 booster with Booster 15-2 slated to be the last one to fly. The SpaceX logistics team brought in around 38 Liquid Nitrogen (LN2) tankers and around 40 LOX tankers. Ship 37 made it through reentry with no major problems. The aft flaps partially came apart, possibly due to hot-staging damage, and then early reentry tore them both open. The port or left side engine chill lines ruptured under the aft flap fairing and punched a hole into the ship’s drive section skirt.

title: SpaceX completes 400th Falcon booster landing on a drone ship
summary: The accomplishment came during Wednesday’s flight of the Starlink 10-56 mission from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station. The touchdown was also SpaceX’s 494th overall successful booster landing.
detailed_news: A Falcon 9 rocket placed another 28 Starlink satellites into orbit shortly after sunrise on Wednesday. The B1095 first stage booster, making its second flight, touched down on the drone ship ‘Just Read the Instructions’ (JRTI) stationed in the Atlantic Ocean east of the Carolinas. The majority of the 400 aquatic landings have occurred on SpaceX’s drone ship, ‘Of Course I Still Love You’ SpaceX released a new batch of photos showing the Feb. 6 liftoff of the company’s first Falcon Heavy rocket from pad 39A at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Liftoff from Space Launch Complex 40 happened at 8:32 p.m. EDT (0032 UTC) The crucial pre-launch engine test has been repeatedly delayed.

title: Meet NASA’s Artemis II Moon Mission Masterminds
summary: As four astronauts venture around the Moon on NASA’s Artemis II test flight in 2026, many people will support the journey from here on Earth. Teams directing operations from the ground include the mission management team, launch control team, flight control team, and the landing and recovery team, each with additional support personnel who are […]
detailed_news: Four astronauts will venture around the Moon on NASA’s Artemis II test flight in 2026. Teams directing operations from the ground include the mission management team, launch control team, flight control team and the landing and recovery team. The teams have managed every aspect of the test flight and ensure NASA is prepared. Orion will reenter Earth’s atmosphere at roughly 25,000 mph to about 20 mph for a parachute-assisted splashdown. Rick Henfling and the team will monitor weather forecasts for landing. Landing and recovery team will be in the hands of Lili Villarreal, who served as deputy flow director for Artemis I.

title: Strap In! NASA Aeroshell Material Takes Extended Space Trip
summary: Components of a NASA technology that could one day help crew and cargo enter harsh planetary environments, like that of Mars, are taking an extended trip to space courtesy of the United States Space Force. On Aug. 21, several pieces of webbing material, known as Zylon, which comprise the straps of the HIAD (Hypersonic Inflatable […]
detailed_news: Several pieces of webbing material, known as Zylon, comprise the straps of the HIAD (Hypersonic Inflatable Aerodynamic Decelerator) aeroshell developed by NASA. The HIAD technology could allow larger spacecraft to safely descend through the atmospheres of celestial bodies like Mars, Venus, and even Saturn’s moon, Titan.

title: NASA Seeks Volunteers to Track Artemis II Mission
summary: NASA seeks volunteers to passively track the Artemis II Orion spacecraft as the crewed mission travels to the Moon and back to Earth. The Artemis II test flight, a launch of the agency’s SLS (Space Launch System) rocket and Orion spacecraft, will send NASA astronauts Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, and Christina Koch, along with CSA […]
detailed_news: Artemis II test flight will send NASA astronauts Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, and Christina Koch, along with CSA (Canadian Space Agency) astronaut Jeremy Hansen, on an approximately 10-day mission around the Moon. The mission, targeted for no later than April 2026, will rely on NASA’s Near Space Network and Deep Space Network for primary communications and tracking support.

title: Portrait of an Astronaut
summary: NASA astronaut Zena Cardman poses for a portrait in a photography studio on March 22, 2024, at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston, Texas. Cardman is currently aboard the International Space Station, where she perform research, technology demonstrations, and maintenance activities. Recently, she took a robotics test on a computer for the portion of the […]
detailed_news: Astronaut Zena Cardman is currently aboard the International Space Station. Cardman launched to the space station on NASA’s SpaceX Crew-11 mission. Members of Crew- 11 will contribute to NASA's Artemis program by simulating Moon landing scenarios that future crews may encounter near the lunar South Pole.

title: Algae bloom chlorophyll South Australia
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: Chlorophyll-a is a key indicator of the presence of algae in the ocean. The bloom, first detected in mid-March 2025 around the Fleurieu Peninsula, is caused by the marine dinoflagellate Karenia mikimotoi. While the algae is not classified as toxic to humans, it can irritate the skin and eyes.

title: ESA and JAXA advance potential Apophis mission collaboration
summary: The Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) has requested funding to participate in the European Space Agency’s (ESA) Rapid Apophis Mission for Space Safety (Ramses).
detailed_news: Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency ( JAXA ) has requested funding to participate in the European Space Agency’s (ESA) Rapid Apophis Mission for Space Safety ( Ramses) Ramses is ESA's proposed mission to rendezvous with the 375 m asteroidApophis and accompany it through a safe but exceptionally close flyby of Earth in 2029. Researchers would use the data gathered by Ramses to improve our ability to defend our planet from any asteroids.

title: Aurora Australis over Concordia station
summary: The Aurora Australis, photographed over Concordia station in July 2025, during the ongoing solar activity maximum, the peak of the Sun's 11-year cycle.
detailed_news: Aurora Australis appears when charged particles from the Sun are guided by Earth’s magnetic field towards the polar regions. Concordia station, perched high on Antarctica’‘Dome C plateau, is one of the most remote research outposts on Earth. Each year, ESA sponsors a medical doctor to live and work at Concordia.

title: Webb investigates complex heart of a cosmic butterfly
summary: The NASA/ESA/CSA James Webb Space Telescope has revealed new details in the core of the Butterfly Nebula, NGC 6302. From the dense, dusty torus that surrounds the star hidden at the centre of the nebula to its outflowing jets, the Webb observations reveal many new discoveries that paint a never-before-seen portrait of a dynamic and structured planetary nebula.
detailed_news: Butterfly Nebula is located about 3400 light-years away in the constellation Scorpius. It is one of the best-studied planetary nebulas in our galaxy. This stunning nebula was previously imaged by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope. Now, Webb has captured a new view of this nebula. Team also spotted light emitted by carbon-based molecules known as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. They form flat, ring-like structures, much like the honeycomb shapes found in beehives. This may be the first-ever evidence of PAHs forming in a oxygen-rich planetary nebula.

title: Avio and Isar Aerospace Win ESA Flight Ticket Initiative Launch Contracts
summary:
The European Space Agency has awarded launch service contracts to Avio and Isar Aerospace under its Flight Ticket Initiative. Announced in October 2023, the Flight Ticket Initiative is a programme run jointly by ESA and the European Union that offers subsidised flight opportunities for European companies and organisations seeking to demonstrate new satellite technologies in […]
The post Avio and Isar Aerospace Win ESA Flight Ticket Initiative Launch Contracts appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: European Space Agency has awarded launch service contracts to Avio and Isar Aerospace under its Flight Ticket Initiative. The contracts will support the launches of the ISISpace Cassini and Infinite Orbits Tom & Jerry missions, both set to fly aboard Isar aerospace rockets from 2026 onwards. Each launch opportunity would carry a maximum award of €5 million.

title: Flight Ticket Initiative: first five missions secured with Avio and Isar Aerospace
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: The Flight Ticket Initiative is a collaboration between the European Space Agency (ESA) and the European Commission. It allows European companies and institutions to test and prove new products and applications in space. It encourages the use of new European launchers. Testing prototypes in space provides valuable insight for research projects and unlocks the market potential of commercial applications.

title: SpaceX successfully launches Super Heavy-Starship on critical test flight
summary: While re-entry heating damaged a protective "skirt" around the the engine bay of the upper stage Starship, along with partially melting a control flap near its hinge, the vehicle remained under control throughout and made it all the way to a powered splashdown in the Indian Ocean as planned.
detailed_news: SpaceX launches its Super Heavy-Starship rocket for the 10th time. The rocket is the most powerful ever built, with 16 million pounds of thrust. A launch try Sunday was called off because of trouble with ground equipment. A second attempt Monday was blocked by cloudy weather. SpaceX's Starship rocket is designed to fly itself back to a launch gantry for mid-air capture. SpaceX has not yet attempted a return-to-launch-site with a Starship. The company fired up nine Merlin main engines at the bottom of a previously-flown Falcon 9 booster. A United Launch Alliance Atlas 5 rocket is set to roll to its launch pad Wednesday. The launch of a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket with a Spanish communications satellite is expected to be shuffled after the Atlas 5 flight. The mission marked the 200th Falcon 9 launch from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 28 Starlink satellites on Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral
summary: The mission is poised to feature the 400th successful booster landing on a droneship. Liftoff from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station is scheduled for 7:10 a.m. EDT (1110 UTC).
detailed_news: The Starlink 10-56 mission will add another 28 Starlink V2 Mini satellites into low Earth orbit roughly an hour after launch. Liftoff from Space Launch Complex 40 is scheduled for 7:10 a.m. EDT (1110 UTC) SpaceX will use the Falcon 9 first stage booster, tail number 1095, to launch this mission, which will fly for a second time.

title: A Great Day for Starship
summary: SpaceX got some much needed good news today with a successful Starship flight test. After three failures in a row, tonight’s suborbital Integrated Flight Test-10 seemed to be flawless with […]
detailed_news: After three failures in a row, tonight’s suborbital Integrated Flight Test-10 seemed to be flawless with launch, payload deployment, in-space engine relight, and soft landings of the booster in the Gulf and the ship in the Indian Ocean. The previous three tests in January, March, and May ended in RUDs — Rapid Unscheduled Disassemblies. Under the $2.9 billion contract with NASA, SpaceX must first fly an uncrewed demonstration flight that lands on the Moon’s South Pole and lifts off again. If he misses that November-December 2026 window, he’ll have to wait another 26 months before the Earth and Mars are properly aligned to try again.
